entry.summary: Monitoring message only. Please disregard.

entry.title: Flood Warning issued April 4 at 6:48AM MDT by NWS Great Falls MT
entry.summary:
...The National Weather Service in Great Falls MT has issued a Flood Warning for the following rivers in Montana...
Lodge Creek near International Border affecting Hill and Blaine Counties.
For the Lodge Creek...including International Border...Minor flooding is forecast.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Lodge Creek near International Border.
* WHEN...From this morning until further notice.
* IMPACTS...At 10.3 feet, April 24 2018 - Lodge Creek rose to near 10.3 feet this year. No impacts were reported, yet areal flooding did occur because of snowmelt in northern Hill and northern Blaine counties.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 6:25 AM MDT Thursday the stage was 7.9 feet. - The creek is expected to crest around 9.3 feet this weekend. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 6:25 AM MDT Thursday was 7.9 feet. - Forecast...The creek will generally be above flood stage for the next several days. The greatest flood impacts will likely be for areas close to the creek. - Flood stage is 7.0 feet. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 9.4 feet on 04/22/2018. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD WARNING IN EFFECT FROM THIS MORNING UNTIL FURTHER NOTICE

entry.title: Flood Warning issued April 4 at 8:41AM EDT until April 6 at 2:51PM EDT by NWS Peachtree City GA
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning is extended for the following rivers in Georgia...
Ocmulgee River near Macon affecting Houston, Bibb, Twiggs, Monroe and Jones Counties.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Ocmulgee River near Macon.
* WHEN...From this afternoon to early Saturday afternoon.
* IMPACTS...At 20 feet, Minor flooding expands. An increasing amount of the Macon GreenWay Ocmulgee Heritage Trail floods north of the Martin Luther King Boulevard bridge. The flood waters will be around one foot deep on portions of the trail and both banks overflow upstream from the bridge. Large portions of agricultural lands well downstream will be under one to three feet of water.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 7:30 AM EDT Thursday the stage was 16.7 feet and rising. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise above flood stage this afternoon to a crest of 19.6 feet tomorrow morning. It will then fall below flood stage Saturday morning. - Flood stage is 18 feet. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 19.6 feet on 04/29/1997.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Bibb, GA; Houston, GA; Jones, GA; Monroe, GA; Twiggs, GA

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD WARNING NOW IN EFFECT FROM THIS AFTERNOON TO EARLY SATURDAY AFTERNOON

entry.title: Winter Storm Warning issued April 4 at 8:32AM EDT until April 5 at 6:00AM EDT by NWS Burlington VT
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Heavy snow. Additional snow accumulations of 3 to 6 inches for a storm total of 5 to 12 inches. Winds gusting as high as 50 mph.
* WHERE...Grand Isle, Western Franklin, Western Chittenden, Western Addison and Western Rutland Counties.
* WHEN...Until 6 AM EDT Friday.
* IMPACTS...Travel will be very difficult, especially this morning. Gusty winds could bring down tree branches and result in scattered power outages.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Snowfall rates could exceed one inch per hour at times this morning.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Grand Isle; Western Franklin; Western Chittenden; Western Addison; Western Rutland

cap:parameter.value: WINTER STORM WARNING IN EFFECT UNTIL 6 AM EDT FRIDAY

entry.summary:

* WHERE...Portions of northern New York and central, northeast, northwest and southern Vermont.
* WHEN...Until 6 AM EDT Friday.
* IMPACTS...Travel will be very difficult, especially this morning into early afternoon. Strong winds could cause tree damage and adversely impact power restoration efforts.

entry.title: Winter Weather Advisory issued April 4 at 8:32AM EDT until April 5 at 6:00AM EDT by NWS Burlington VT
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Snow. Additional snow accumulations of 2 to 5 inches for a storm total of 3 to 8 inches. Winds gusting as high as 50 mph.
* WHERE...Portions of northern New York and central, northwest and southern Vermont.
* WHEN...Until 6 AM EDT Friday.
* IMPACTS...Travel could be very difficult. The hazardous conditions are likely to impact the commute this morning. Gusty winds could bring down tree branches and result in patchy blowing snow.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued April 4 at 8:05AM EDT by NWS Greenville-Spartanburg SC
entry.summary: Intermittent snow showers are expected across the high elevations of the North Carolina mountains through Friday. By Friday evening, accumulations ranging from a dusting to up to 3 inches are expected across much of the area above 3500 feet. Locally higher amounts of 6 inches or more are expected on the high peaks and ridge tops along the Tennessee border. Motorists traveling across the high elevations through Friday should use extra caution.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Madison; Yancey; Mitchell; Swain; Haywood; Graham

cap:parameter.value: ACCUMULATING SNOW EXPECTED ACROSS THE HIGH ELEVATIONS OF THE NORTH CAROLINA MOUNTAINS THROUGH FRIDAY

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued April 4 at 5:44AM MDT by NWS Great Falls MT
entry.summary:
Patchy locally dense fog is currently being observed over portions of Central Montana. Local visibility reductions down to less than one half mile through at least 8 AM are possible.
Travelers and pedestrians should be prepared for highly variable road conditions, including sudden drops in visibility below one half mile. Slow down and use low beam headlights when driving through fog.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Southern High Plains; Eastern Pondera and Eastern Teton; Western and Central Chouteau County; Cascade County below 5000ft

cap:parameter.value: Patchy Locally Dense Fog has formed in Central Montana

entry.title: Flood Warning issued April 4 at 7:43AM EDT by NWS Mount Holly NJ
entry.summary:
...The National Weather Service in Mount Holly NJ has issued a Flood Warning for the following rivers in New Jersey...
Passaic River Above Singac affecting Essex, Morris and Passaic Counties.
For the Passaic River...including Singac...Minor flooding is forecast.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Passaic River above Singac.
* WHEN...From this afternoon until further notice.
* IMPACTS...At 8.5 feet, Portions of the Wayne Town Center parking lot begin to flood. Hobson Avenue and Riverlawn Drive in Wayne begin to flood. Fairfield Road, Fayette Avenue, and Riversedge Road in Wayne can flood as water backs up the Pompton River. Lincoln Boulevard in Lincoln Park can also flood due to backwater up the Pompton river. The Pequannock River Park also floods. At 9.0 feet, Two Bridges Road in Fairfield is subject to closures. At 9.5 feet, Camp Lane and Marginal Road in Fairfield begins to flood. At 10.0 feet, Two Bridges Road in Fairfield begins to flood. Finns Drive, Siesta Drive, and Market street in Wayne are all susceptible to flooding. William Street, Louis Street, and Zeliff Avenue in Little Falls can begin to flood. Portions of Lincoln Park become impassable. The Meadows Golf Club in Lincoln Park floods.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 6:45 AM EDT Thursday the stage was 7.9 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise above flood stage this afternoon and continue rising to a crest of 9.5 feet early tomorrow afternoon. - Flood stage is 8.5 feet. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 9.5 feet on 12/30/2023. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Essex, NJ; Morris, NJ; Passaic, NJ

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD WARNING IN EFFECT FROM THIS AFTERNOON UNTIL FURTHER NOTICE

entry.title: Flood Warning issued April 4 at 6:53AM EDT until April 4 at 10:00AM EDT by NWS Mount Holly NJ
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall continues.
* WHERE...A portion of southeast Pennsylvania, including the following county, Montgomery.
* WHEN...Until 1000 AM EDT.
* IMPACTS...Flooding of rivers, creeks, streams, and other low-lying and flood-prone locations is imminent or occurring. Streams continue to rise due to excess runoff from earlier rainfall.

entry.title: Fire Weather Watch issued April 4 at 4:24AM MDT until April 6 at 8:00PM MDT by NWS El Paso Tx/Santa Teresa NM
entry.summary:
...CRITICAL FIRE WEATHER CONDITIONS MAY DEVELOP SATURDAY AFTERNOON...
.A combination of increasing west/northwest winds, low relative humidity, and continued drying of fine fuels will potentially produce critical fire weather conditions over most of the lowlands east of Deming.
The National Weather Service in El Paso Tx/Santa Teresa has issued a Fire Weather Watch for gusty winds and low humidity, which is in effect from Saturday afternoon through early Saturday evening.
* AFFECTED AREA...Fire Weather Zone 055 Texas Fire Weather Zone 055 El Paso County, Fire Weather Zone 056 Texas Fire Weather Zone 056 Hudspeth County and Fire Weather Zone 112 South Central Lowlands and Southern Rio Grande Valley/BLM/GLZ.
* TIMING...Beginning late Saturday morning into early Saturday evening.
* WINDS...West 25 to 35 mph with gusts up to 50 mph.
* RELATIVE HUMIDITY...From 11 to 14 percent.
* TEMPERATURES...From the upper 50s to mid 60s.
* IMPACTS...Any fires that develop will likely spread rapidly. Outdoor burning is not recommended.
entry.cap:areaDesc: South Central Lowlands And Southern Rio Grande Valley; El Paso; Hudspeth

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued April 4 at 5:57AM EDT by NWS Greenville-Spartanburg SC
entry.summary:
Sustained winds of 10 to 20 mph, with gusts as high as 30 mph are expected across the North Carolina Piedmont today. Meanwhile, relative humidity of 25 to 30 percent is expected across the area this afternoon. These conditions combined with dry vegetation will enhance the potential for the start and spread of wildfires across the area.
Please refer to your local burn permitting authorities on whether you can burn today. If you do burn, use extreme caution since fires can quickly get out of hand under these conditions.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Iredell; Davie; Catawba; Rowan; Cleveland; Lincoln; Gaston; Mecklenburg; Cabarrus; Union; Greater Rutherford

* WHEN...From 9 PM this evening to 3 PM PDT Saturday.

* IMPACTS...At 5.0 feet, Open adjacent land begins to flood. Waters rise around Wilderness Island Park. At 6.0 feet, John E. Murrin Park begins to flood. Hershfield Park floods. The athletic fields begin to take on water. Parking lots and Hershfield Park Place floods. Carlough Field floods. At 7.0 feet, Back Beach Park in Wanaque begins to flood. The light industrial area off of Lakeside Avenue in Pompton Lakes floods. VFW Way in Pompton Lakes begins to flood. Backyards flood on Henderson Court and Hill Court in Pompton Lakes.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 4:10 AM EDT Thursday the stage was 5.5 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise above flood stage late this morning to a crest of 6.2 feet this evening. It will then fall below flood stage late tomorrow morning. - Flood stage is 6.0 feet. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 6.1 feet on 03/31/2010. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.title: Beach Hazards Statement issued April 4 at 4:39AM EDT until April 4 at 8:00PM EDT by NWS Newport/Morehead City NC
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Dangerous rip currents, large breaking waves expected, and strong longshore currents in the surf zone.
* WHERE...The beaches from Cape Hatteras to Surf City.
* WHEN...From 8 AM EDT this morning through this evening.
* IMPACTS...Rip currents can sweep even the best swimmers away from shore into deeper water. Dangerous shore break can throw a swimmer or surfer head first into the bottom causing neck and back injuries. Strong longshore currents will create dangerous swimming conditions.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued April 4 at 4:26AM EDT by NWS Jackson KY
entry.summary:
Mixed rain and snow showers in the lower elevations and snow showers above 2500 feet, will impact the area through mid morning. Above 2500 feet on Pine Mountain and Black Mountain, some light accumulations of a dusting to around an inch are forecast, generally on grassy and elevated surfaces. However, during the heavier snow showers, some roadways above 2500 feet could become snow or slush covered for a time, with this most probable on roadways above 3000 feet that cross Black Mountain in Harlan County such as KY 179 and KY 160. Other roadways that may be affected by winter travel include US 119, US 421, KY 38, KY 2010, and the Little Shepherd Trail.
If traveling across Pine and Black Mountains this morning, expect some slick spots. Slow down and allow extra time to reach your destination.

cap:parameter.value: Minor Snow Accumulations Possible Above 2500 Feet This Morning

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued April 4 at 4:22AM EDT by NWS Greenville-Spartanburg SC
entry.summary:
Sustained winds of 10 to 20 mph, with gusts as high as 30 mph are expected across northeast Georgia this afternoon. Meanwhile, relative humidity of 25 to 30 percent is expected across the Piedmont. * WHAT...Minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Taunton River near Bridgewater.
* WHEN...From this afternoon until further notice.
* IMPACTS...At 9.0 feet, Backwater flooding from the Taunton River will cause flooding of lower Purchade Brook in Middleboro. This will cause Woloski Park to become impassable by most vehicles for an extended period of time. Beware of the dangers of crossing flooded roadways. The water may be deeper than you think. Floodwaters have the ability to damage roadways. Heed the advice of local officials, and evacuate if asked to do so.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 3:45 AM EDT Thursday the stage was 7.2 feet. - Bankfull stage is 8.0 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise above flood stage this afternoon and continue rising to a crest of 9.5 feet early tomorrow afternoon. - Flood stage is 8.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.title: Coastal Flood Warning issued April 4 at 4:16AM EDT until April 4 at 10:00AM EDT by NWS Boston/Norton MA
entry.summary:
* WHAT...One to two feet of inundation above ground level expected in low-lying areas near shorelines and tidal waterways (4.5 to 13.6 feet Mean Lower Low Water).
* WHERE...Eastern Essex, Suffolk, Eastern Norfolk, Eastern Plymouth, Barnstable, Dukes and Nantucket Counties.
* WHEN...Until 10 AM EDT this morning.
* IMPACTS...Some vulnerable coastal roads become impassable around high tide. Flooding 1 to 2 feet deep affects some coastal roads and low lying areas from Revere and Winthrop through Boston to Hull, Braintree, and Quincy. Splashover and debris may wash onto coastal roads when large waves occur. Most roads remain passable. Flooding up to one foot deep affects coastal roads on the North Shore from Salem to Gloucester and Newburyport. Rough surf will cause flooding on some coastal roads around the time of high tide due to splashover. Roads remain passable. Low lying areas and roads near Nantucket Harbor, including Easy Street, may experience pockets of shallow flooding less than one foot deep. Roads remain passable. Shallow pockets of flooding less than one foot deep affect low lying areas in Provincetown, mainly near the airport and Race Point Road. In Truro, flooding up to one foot deep affects low lying areas near Pamet Harbor and along the Pamet River. Some roads become impassable. Flooding 1 to 2 feet deep affects low lying areas around Edgartown Harbor, Vineyard Haven, and Oak Bluffs. This includes the Chappy Ferry Dock in Edgartown, Five Corners and Beach Road in Vineyard Haven, and East Chop Drive in Oak Bluffs. Splashover from waves affects Sea View Avenue in Oak Bluffs.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Eastern Essex; Suffolk; Eastern Norfolk; Eastern Plymouth; Barnstable; Dukes; Nantucket

entry.summary:
...FIRE WEATHER WATCH IN EFFECT FROM SATURDAY AFTERNOON THROUGH SATURDAY EVENING FOR WARM, DRY AND WINDY CONDITIONS...
The National Weather Service in Norman has issued a Fire Weather Watch for far western Oklahoma and western north Texas, which is in effect from Saturday afternoon through Saturday evening.
* WINDS...Southwest 25 to 35 mph with gusts over 50 mph possible.
* RELATIVE HUMIDITY...As low as 15 percent.
* TEMPERATURES...Up to 80.
* IMPACTS...Any fires that develop will likely spread rapidly. Outdoor burning is not recommended.
* SEVERITY...
FUELS (ERC)...50th-69th percentile...3 (out of 5).
WEATHER...Critical...3 (out of 5).
FIRE ENVIRONMENT... 6 (out of 10).

entry.title: Winter Storm Warning issued April 4 at 4:10AM EDT until April 4 at 8:00PM EDT by NWS Gray ME
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Heavy snow and sleet. Additional snow accumulations between 5 and 11 inches for a storm total of 6 to 17 inches and sleet accumulations around one third of an inch. Winds gusting as high as 55 mph.
* WHERE...Portions of south central and southwest Maine and central and southern New Hampshire.
* WHEN...Until 8 PM EDT this evening.
* IMPACTS...Moderate snow with periods of heavy snow with potential for a foot plus of accumulation will create hazardous travel conditions across the region. Strong, gusty winds are also expected with the snowstorm, which could cause damage to trees and power lines. Travel is not recommended as heavy snowfall and very low visibility will create extremely dangerous driving conditions. The hazardous conditions will impact the morning commute, with impacts potentially lingering into the evening commute.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...This is a long-duration, multi-faceted event. Intensity will continue increase this morning when some of the heaviest rates may fall accompanied by strong, gusty winds. Be prepared for a prolonged duration of impact. Very strong downslope winds west of the White Mountains are expected late tonight and Thursday morning.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Coastal York; Coastal Cumberland; Sagadahoc; Lincoln; Knox; Coastal Waldo; Sullivan; Merrimack; Cheshire; Eastern Hillsborough; Interior Rockingham; Coastal Rockingham; Western And Central Hillsborough

entry.summary:

* WHERE...Sagadahoc, Lincoln, Knox and Coastal Waldo Counties.
* WHEN...Until 10 AM EDT this morning.
* IMPACTS...Flooding of lots, parks, and roads with only isolated road closures expected.

* IMPACTS...Travel could be very difficult. The hazardous conditions could impact the Thursday morning and evening commutes.

* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring.
* WHERE...Youghiogheny River at Connellsville.
* WHEN...Until late this morning.
* IMPACTS...At 12.0 feet, Flooding begins in the vicinity of Yough Park. At 14.0 feet, Several inches of water floods basements of about 30 homes along left bank. River is bankful along the left bank just downstream from the Crawford Street Bridge. Water reaches the level of the Hurricane Ivan flood of September 18, 2004. At 14.1 feet, Water reaches level of March 3, 2015.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 3:15 AM EDT Thursday the stage was 12.4 feet. - Bankfull stage is 12.0 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 3:15 AM EDT Thursday was 14.7 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to fall below flood stage early this morning and continue falling to 5.8 feet early Tuesday morning. - Flood stage is 12.0 feet. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 12.5 feet on 02/19/2000. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

* WHAT...Moderate flooding is occurring and moderate flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Ohio River at Pittsburgh.
* WHEN...Until late this evening.
* IMPACTS...At 18.0 feet, Water begins to flow onto the Monongahela Parking Wharf. At 19.0 feet, Water begins to flow onto the North Shore riverwalk between the stadiums. At 19.5 feet, The Monongahela Parking Wharf is completely flooded. At 20.0 feet, Water is up to one foot deep in the lower areas of the North Shore Riverwalk. At 22.0 feet, The Tenth Street Bypass floods. At 22.5 feet, The fountain plaza is flooded. At 24.0 feet, Water enters the outer pool of the fountain. At 24.9 feet, Water entes the inner pool of the fountain. At 25.0 feet, The Parkway Central (also known as the bathtub) is closed by flooding. Lower North Side businesses are affected. At 26.0 feet, State Correctional Institution Pittsburgh is impacted. At 27.6 feet, The fountain in Point State Park is completely submerged. At 28.0 feet, Pumping operations begin on Neville Island. The Wood Street T station facilities are impacted. Fort Pitt Boulevard is closed. At 29.0 feet, River Avenue on the North Side begins to flood. At 30.0 feet, 200 manufacturing concerns and companies in Pittsburgh are affected by flooding. Acrisure Stadium playing field is flooded. Point state park is flooded to the Portal Bridge.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 3:30 AM EDT Thursday the stage was 28.1 feet. - Bankfull stage is 18.0 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 3:30 AM EDT Thursday was 28.2 feet. - Forecast...The river will rise to 28.3 feet this morning. It will then fall below flood stage late this afternoon to 19.2 feet tomorrow evening. It will rise to 19.5 feet Saturday morning. It will then fall again and remain below flood stage. - Flood stage is 25.0 feet. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 28.4 feet on 01/06/2005. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

At 41.0 feet, Water street in Wheeling is flooded near the intersctions with 12th, 21st, 45th, and 48th Streets. At 42.0 feet, Flooding reaches the intersection of 39th and McColloch Streets and the intersection of Georgia and North Front Streets in Wheeling. At 42.7 feet, Much of southern half of Wheeling Island is flooded and up to Erie Street on the northern half of the island. Low lying sections of South Wheeling are flooded.

* WHAT...Moderate flooding is occurring and moderate flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Stillwater Creek at Uhrichsville.
* WHEN...Until early Sunday morning.
* IMPACTS...At 10.0 feet, Stillwater Creek comes out of its banks in several locations resulting in overflowing in poor drainage areas. Minor flooding of low lying areas begins. At 11.5 feet, Flood waters of Stillwater Creek will reach the intersection of East 12th Street and North Main Street in Uhrichsville and approach Newport Street. Little Stillwater Creek will flood most of Phac Park along with portions of Wilson Road in Dennison. At 12.9 feet, Numerous low land areas are flooded. Stillwater Creek begins to flood portions of Newport Street in Uhrichsville. Homes along Park Drive begin to flood. Sections of Wilson Road near Phac Park are flooded. At 13.3 feet, Flood waters reach Newport Avenue in Uhrichsville as well as East 12th Street and North Main Street half way to East 11th Street. Phac Park along Little Stillwater Creek in Dennison is flooded. At 17.8 feet, Flooding occurs in the west and north side of Uhrichsville (Main Street, West 5th Street, the east end of 4th Street, and the east end of Franklin Street.) Also flooded are areas in Uhrichsville and Dennison along Little Stillwater Creek and the west end of Newport.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 3:00 AM EDT Thursday the stage was 15.6 feet. - Bankfull stage is 7.6 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 3:00 AM EDT Thursday was 15.6 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise to a crest of 15.9 feet this morning. * IMPACTS...At 15.0 feet, Overflowing of poor drainage and low lying areas will result in minor flooding along wills creek. At 16.0 feet, Basement flooding begins through floor drains and other sewer connections. Local interruptions in sanitary service may occur along Gordon's Run from 3rd Street to 6th Street. At 17.0 feet, Water overflows wills Creek Valley Road to a depth of 2 feet. Water reaches a depth of 1 foot on North Eighth Street. At 18.0 feet, Flood waters begin effecting apartments along Wills Creek Valley Road. Southgate Parkway will also begin flooding near Woodlawn Avenue. At 20.0 feet, Flood waters reach residential areas on the west side of Cambridge. At 22.0 feet, The North 8th Street Bridge near the school campus is impassable. Flood waters reach Wills Creek Valley Drive near the County Road 35 Bridge. The north side of Cambridge is close to being cut off from access. Water from Wills Creek will flood the west end of Cambridge. At 23.0 feet, Flood waters are expected to reach the Cambridge Square Plaza on Route 209. South 10th Street and Orchard Avenue should also begin to feel the effects of the rising waters. Seek higher ground and do not attempt to cross flooded roadways.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 3:15 AM EDT Thursday the stage was 21.2 feet. - Bankfull stage is 13.0 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 3:15 AM EDT Thursday was 21.2 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise to a crest of 21.2 feet this morning. * IMPACTS...At 13.0 feet, Water reaches low lying areas between Tuscarawas and Walhonding Rivers just upstream of the confluence of the two rivers. At 15.0 feet, Low areas are flooded and water reaches a few homes along Route 16 south of Coshocton and along County Route 1A north of Coshocton. At 16.0 feet, Flood waters begin to affect the Lake Park area along the Walhonding River and begins backwater flooding along Mill Creek north of Lake Park and along Route 83. Flood waters will begin to enter yards in low-lying areas along County Route 1A.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 3:00 AM EDT Thursday the stage was 14.1 feet. - Bankfull stage is 13.0 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise above flood stage Saturday evening and continue rising to a crest of 15.8 feet Sunday evening. - Flood stage is 15.0 feet. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 16.9 feet on 02/13/2019. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.title: Red Flag Warning issued April 4 at 1:14AM MDT until April 5 at 9:00PM MDT by NWS Albuquerque NM
entry.summary:
...RED FLAG WARNING IN EFFECT 11 AM TO 9 AM FRIDAY FOR THE NORTHWEST PLATEAU, RIO GRANDE VALLEY, SANDIA AND MANZANO MOUNTAINS BELOW SNOWPACK AND ALL OF EASTERN NEW MEXICO DUE TO STRONG WINDS, LOW HUMIDITY AND AN UNSTABLE ATMOSPHERE...
...FIRE WEATHER WATCH IN EFFECT SATURDAY AFTERNOON AND EARLY EVENING FOR THE MIDDLE RIO GRANDE VALLEY AND ALL OF EASTERN NEW MEXICO DUE TO STRONG WINDS AND LOW HUMIDITY...
.Widespread critical fire weather conditions are expected on Friday as winds increase ahead of an approaching storm system. These strong winds combined with low humidity will allow for rapid fire spread in dry and receptive fuels. Strong south to southwest winds will peak during the afternoon hours, but will remain elevated through the evening and overnight Friday night. A strong cold front will surge from west to east early Saturday. Very strong westerly winds will develop behind the front and with continued low humidity values, critical fire weather conditions are expected once again on Saturday for the Rio Grande Valley and all of eastern New Mexico.
The National Weather Service in Albuquerque has issued a Red Flag Warning...which is in effect from 11 AM to 9 PM MDT Friday. The Fire Weather Watch is no longer in effect.
* AREA AND TIMING...This includes the Northwest Plateau (Zone 101), Upper Rio Grande Valley and Lower Chama River Valley (Zone 121), and the Sandia and Manzano Mountains below snowpack (Zone 124) from late Friday morning through Friday evening.
* 20 FOOT WINDS...South to southwest 25 to 35 mph with gusts between 45 and 60 mph.
* RELATIVE HUMIDITY...Minimum values between 10 and 15 percent.
* IMPACTS...Any fires that develop will likely spread rapidly. Outdoor burning is not recommended.

cap:parameter.value: RED FLAG WARNING IN EFFECT FROM 11 AM TO 9 PM MDT FRIDAY

entry.title: Red Flag Warning issued April 4 at 1:14AM MDT until April 5 at 9:00PM MDT by NWS Albuquerque NM
entry.summary:
...RED FLAG WARNING IN EFFECT 11 AM TO 9 AM FRIDAY FOR THE NORTHWEST PLATEAU, RIO GRANDE VALLEY, SANDIA AND MANZANO MOUNTAINS BELOW SNOWPACK AND ALL OF EASTERN NEW MEXICO DUE TO STRONG WINDS, LOW HUMIDITY AND AN UNSTABLE ATMOSPHERE...
...FIRE WEATHER WATCH IN EFFECT SATURDAY AFTERNOON AND EARLY EVENING FOR THE MIDDLE RIO GRANDE VALLEY AND ALL OF EASTERN NEW MEXICO DUE TO STRONG WINDS AND LOW HUMIDITY...
.Widespread critical fire weather conditions are expected on Friday as winds increase ahead of an approaching storm system. These strong winds combined with low humidity will allow for rapid fire spread in dry and receptive fuels. Strong south to southwest winds will peak during the afternoon hours, but will remain elevated through the evening and overnight Friday night. A strong cold front will surge from west to east early Saturday. Very strong westerly winds will develop behind the front and with continued low humidity values, critical fire weather conditions are expected once again on Saturday for the Rio Grande Valley and all of eastern New Mexico.
The National Weather Service in Albuquerque has issued a Red Flag Warning...which is in effect from 11 AM to 9 PM MDT Friday. A Fire Weather Watch has also been issued. This Fire Weather Watch is in effect from Saturday afternoon through Saturday evening.
* AREA AND TIMING...This includes the Middle Rio Grande Valley (Zone 106), and all of eastern New Mexico (Zones 104, 123, 125, and 126) from late Friday morning through Friday evening and again Saturday afternoon through Saturday evening.
* 20 FOOT WINDS...On Friday, south to southwest 25 to 35 mph with gusts between 45 and 50 mph. On Saturday, west 35 to 45 mph with gusts to 65 mph.
* RELATIVE HUMIDITY...Minimum values between 8 and 15 percent each day.
* IMPACTS...Any fires that develop will likely spread rapidly. Outdoor burning is not recommended.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Northeast Plains; Middle Rio Grande Valley; Northeast Highlands; Central Highlands; East Central Plains

Water close to one residence at Shelby CR 1000S and CR 900W.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 10:30 PM EDT Wednesday the stage was 13.2 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 10:30 PM EDT Wednesday was 13.2 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise to a crest of 13.4 feet just after midnight tonight. It will then fall below flood stage early Friday afternoon. - Flood stage is 11.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

.Repeated rounds of showers and thunderstorms Monday and Tuesday brought 1 to 4 inches of rainfall to most parts of central and southern Indiana. This is bringing rises to area waterways, with minor flooding occurring along many area rivers and moderate flooding along the Mississinewa at Ridgeville. Persons with interests along area rivers should closely monitor forecasts for updates.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Wabash River at Riverton.
* WHEN...Until Sunday, April 14.
* IMPACTS...At 18.0 feet, Extensive lowland flooding is in progress. High water surrounds many river cabins. Access to most river cabins is by boat only. Levees begin to protect farmland. Extensive flooding of Leaverton Park occurs in Palestine, Illinois.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 10:00 PM EDT Wednesday /9:00 PM CDT Wednesday/ the stage was 15.4 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 10:00 PM EDT Wednesday /9:00 PM CDT Wednesday/ was 15.4 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise to a crest of 18.0 feet early Tuesday afternoon. It will then fall below flood stage Saturday, April 13. - Flood stage is 15.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

.Repeated rounds of showers and thunderstorms Monday and Tuesday brought 1 to 4 inches of rainfall to most parts of central and southern Indiana. Illinois River...
The following river information is based on future predicted rainfall. The exact amount, intensity, timing, and location of the rain that will occur is still uncertain. entry.title: High Surf Advisory issued April 3 at 3:15PM HST until April 5 at 6:00PM HST by NWS Honolulu HI
entry.summary:
...HIGH SURF ADVISORY FOR EAST FACING SHORES OF KAUAI OAHU MOLOKAI MAUI AND THE BIG ISLAND UNTIL 6 PM HST FRIDAY...
.Strong trade winds near and upstream of the islands will generate large and rough surf along east facing shores for the next couple of days.
* WHAT...Surf of 8 to 12 feet.
* WHERE...East facing shores of Kauai, Oahu, Molokai, Maui, and the Big Island.
* WHEN...Until 6 PM HST Friday, though this advisory may be extended later.
* IMPACTS...Moderate. Strong breaking waves and strong currents will make swimming dangerous.

entry.title: Wind Advisory issued April 3 at 3:14PM HST until April 4 at 6:00PM HST by NWS Honolulu HI
entry.summary:
...WIND ADVISORY IN EFFECT THROUGH THURSDAY AFTERNOON OVER WINDIER AREAS OF ALL ISLANDS...
.Strong high pressure will continue north of the Hawaiian Islands today. Strong and gusty easterly trade winds will exceed wind advisory thresholds in windier areas across the state through Thursday. Portions of the advisory area may need to be extended through Friday as well.
* WHAT...East winds 25 to 35 mph with localized gusts over 50 mph.
* WHERE...Portions of Kahoolawe, Kauai, Lanai, Maui, Molokai, Oahu and the Big Island.
* WHEN...Until 6 PM HST Thursday.
* IMPACTS...Winds this strong can tear off shingles, knock down tree branches, blow away tents and awnings and make it difficult to steer, especially for drivers of high profile vehicles.

entry.title: Flood Warning issued April 3 at 9:00PM EDT by NWS Jacksonville FL
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning is extended for the following rivers in Georgia...
Altamaha River At Baxley affecting Toombs, Appling, Tattnall and Wayne Counties.
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Florida... Georgia...
Santa Fe River At Three Rivers Estates affecting Columbia, Gilchrist and Suwannee Counties.
Satilla River At Atkinson affecting Brantley County.
Additional information is available at https://water.weather.gov/ahps2/forecasts.php?wfo=jax.
The next statement will be issued Thursday evening at 900 PM EDT.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Santa Fe River at Three Rivers Estates.
* WHEN...Until further notice.
* IMPACTS...At 16.0 feet, Lowland flooding begins on SW Santa Fe Drive south of Santa Fe Road in Columbia County. At 16.3 feet, Florida Fish and Wildlife Commission begins enforcement of a no wake zone on the Santa Fe River from the unnamed island 1.5 miles downstream of the Wilson's Spring Boat Ramp to the confluence with the Suwannee River and on the Ichetucknee River upstream to the US 27 bridge. At 17.0 feet, Water begins to enter backyards of residences on Santa Fe Road in Columbia County and on River Run Road in Suwannee County. At 18.0 feet, Water begins to flood River Run Road in Suwannee County. At 18.8 feet, Florida Fish and Wildlife Commission expands the no wake zone restriction further upstream on the Santa Fe River from the unnamed island 1.5 miles downstream on the Wilson's Spring Boat Ramp to one-half mile upstream of the State Road 47 bridge. At 19.0 feet, Water begins to enter backyards of residences along the Ichetucknee River. At 19.8 feet, Waters begins to affect homes in the Hollingsworth Bluff area at State Route 47. At 20.0 feet, Access to homes on Santa Fe Road below SW Riverside Avenue becomes restricted in Columbia. Flooding begins on Santa Fe and Wilson Springs Road.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 7:00 PM EDT Wednesday the stage was 17.3 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise to 18.5 feet Monday evening. Additional rises are possible thereafter. - Flood stage is 17.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Columbia, FL; Gilchrist, FL; Suwannee, FL

entry.title: Air Quality Alert issued April 3 at 4:58PM PDT by NWS San Diego CA
entry.summary:
The South Coast AQMD has issued an air quality alert due to increased particle pollution from blowing dust. The air quality alert is in effect 11 AM Thursday through 5 AM Friday.
In areas directly impacted by high levels of windblown dust, limit your exposure by remaining indoors with windows and doors closed and avoiding vigorous physical activity. Run your air conditioner or an air purifier. If temperatures allow, avoid using whole house fans or swamp coolers that bring in outside air.
Exposure to high particle pollution levels can cause serious health problems, including asthma attacks, heart and lung disease symptoms, and increased risk of respiratory infections. People with heart or lung diseases should follow their doctor's advice for dealing with episodes of unhealthy air quality. Children, older adults, and people with respiratory or heart disease should avoid prolonged exposure and strenuous activities when particle pollution levels are high.
To help minimize outdoor particle pollution levels: * Carpool, telecommute, reduce trips, or take public transportation * Slow down if driving on dirt roads * Stabilize loose soils
Levels of particle pollution can vary hour by hour and by location depending on wind conditions.
To view current and forecasted air quality levels, visit the South Coast Air Quality Management District website at aqmd.gov or download the mobile app at www.aqmd.gov/mobileapp. Additional details for this air quality alert may be available at www.aqmd.gov/advisory.
To view current and forecasted air quality levels, visit the Mojave Desert Air Quality Management District website at mdaqmd.ca.gov. Additional details for this air quality alert may be available at www.mdaqmd.ca.gov/advisories.
To view current and forecast air quality within Imperial County visit the Imperial County Air Quality website at http://www.imperialvalleyair.org/ or follow ICAPCD on Twitter, facebook or Instagram (@county_air).
entry.cap:areaDesc: Coachella Valley; San Gorgonio Pass Near Banning

To view current and forecast air quality within Imperial County visit the Imperial County Air Quality website at http://www.imperialvalleyair.org/ or follow ICAPCD on Twitter, facebook or Instagram (@county_air).

entry.title: Flood Advisory issued April 3 at 4:18PM EDT until April 4 at 11:30AM EDT by NWS Upton NY
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Flooding along the Hudson River caused by storm surge and rainfall during times of high tide this afternoon and particularly early thursday morning.
* WHERE...A portion of southeast New York, including the following counties, Orange, Putnam, Rockland and Westchester.
* WHEN...Until 1130 AM EDT Thursday.
* IMPACTS...Minor flooding in vulnerable riverfront communities. Expect around 1 to 2 ft of inundation above ground level in low lying, vulnerable areas. This will result in scattered road closures and cause widespread flooding of low lying property including parking lots, parks, lawns, and homes/businesses and basements near the waterfront. Vehicles parking in vulnerable areas near the waterfront will likely become flooded.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 417 PM EDT, National Weather Service New York NY has issued this Flood Advisory with expectation of flooding along the Hudson River during the times of high tide this afternoon into Thursday morning, caused by storm surge and rainfall. - In addition, rainfall amounts of 1 to 1.5 inches are expected over the area. This additional rain will exacerbate flooding issues. - Some locations that will experience flooding include... Stony Point, Piermont, Cold Spring, Croton On The Hudson, Garrison Landing, Newburgh, Ossining and Cortland. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued April 3 at 1:06PM PDT by NWS Reno NV
entry.summary:
* A strong cold front is moving through the Sierra and western NV through Thursday, bringing gusty winds, much colder temperatures, and chances for snow showers.
* Gusty southwest winds will develop this afternoon north of Highway 50 and shift to the Eastern Sierra of Mono and Mineral counties overnight into Thursday morning. This will impact outdoor activities, produce bumpy airplane rides, and cause gusty cross winds for high-profile vehicles, especially along Highway 395, Highway 95, and I-580. Wind gusts along the Sierra crest will exceed 80 mph.
* Snow showers across northeast CA and the Sierra today will then push across the region through Friday. Roads will be slick in the Sierra, especially at night. The higher April sun angle will limit accumulations during the daytime hours. Prepare for possible delays if your plans include travel across the Sierra. Total snow accumulations: Above 7000 feet in Greater Lake Tahoe: greater than 6 inches on the west side of Lake Tahoe and 1 to 2 inches in the Carson Range. Above 7000 feet in Mono County: 3 to 12 inches with up to 18 inches along the highest Sierra crest. Below 7000 feet in Mono County: a trace up to 4 inches. Lowest Nevada valleys: light snow showers, but little or no accumulation.
* Unusually cold air for early April settles into the area with daytime temperatures 15-20 degrees below normal Thursday and Friday followed by only slight warming over the weekend. Hard freezes are almost a certainty each night, even for lower western NV valleys beginning Thursday night. Be ready to protect sensitive plants, wrap exposed irrigation systems, and watch out for vulnerable populations and pets.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Surprise Valley California; Lassen-Eastern Plumas-Eastern Sierra Counties; Greater Lake Tahoe Area; Mono; Mineral and Southern Lyon Counties; Greater Lake Tahoe Area; Greater Reno-Carson City-Minden Area; Western Nevada Basin and Range including Pyramid Lake; Northern Washoe County

entry.summary:
...GUSTY WINDS AND DRY VEGETATION WILL MAINTAIN A HIGH FIRE THREAT...

entry.title: Coastal Flood Warning issued April 3 at 3:27PM EDT until April 4 at 10:00AM EDT by NWS Upton NY
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Up to 2 ft of inundation above ground level expected in vulnerable areas near the waterfront and shoreline.
* WHERE...Southern Middlesex and Southern New London Counties.
* WHEN...From 4 AM to 10 AM EDT Thursday.
* IMPACTS...Minor to locally moderate flooding possible in the most vulnerable locations near the waterfront and shoreline early Thursday morning. Expect up to 2 feet of inundation above ground level in low lying, vulnerable areas. Some roads and low lying property including parking lots, parks, lawns and homes/businesses with basements near the waterfront will experience shallow flooding.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...The coverage and magnitude of flooding early Thursday morning will be dependent on track of low pressure, and timing of windshift from easterly gales to northwest gales. This will be refined over the next 24 hours.

cap:parameter.value: COASTAL FLOOD WARNING IN EFFECT FROM 4 AM TO 10 AM EDT THURSDAY

entry.title: Coastal Flood Warning issued April 3 at 3:27PM EDT until April 4 at 10:00AM EDT by NWS Upton NY
entry.summary:
* WHAT...1 1/2 to 2 1/2 ft of inundation above ground level expected in vulnerable areas near the waterfront and shoreline with this evening and early Thursday morning high tides.
* WHERE...In Connecticut, Southern Fairfield and Southern New Haven Counties. In New York, Southern Westchester, Bronx, Northwest Suffolk, Northern Queens and Northern Nassau Counties.
* WHEN...From 4 PM Wednesday to 10 AM EDT Thursday.
* COASTAL FLOOD IMPACTS...Widespread flooding of vulnerable areas near the waterfront and shoreline, including roads, parking lots, parks, lawns, and homes and businesses with basements near the waterfront. Numerous road closures are likely, and vehicles parked in vulnerable areas near the waterfront will likely become flooded. Flooding will also extend inland from the waterfront along tidal rivers and bays, including the Hudson River.
* SHORELINE IMPACTS...Breaking waves of 3 to 6 ft this evening, along with elevated water levels, will result in beach erosion with scattered damage to shoreline structures. Wave splashover over bulkheads and seawalls will exacerbate flooding of shoreline roadways and properties.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...The combination of heavy rain, runoff and elevated water levels this evening and early Thursday morning may cause localized flash flooding along some shoreline roads and properties. The coverage and magnitude of flooding early Thursday morning will be dependent on track of low pressure, and timing of windshift from easterly gales to northwest gales. To account for this forecast uncertainty, a slight upward safety margin has been applied to the forecast water levels.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Southern Fairfield; Southern New Haven; Southern Westchester; Bronx; Northwest Suffolk; Northern Queens; Northern Nassau

cap:parameter.value: COASTAL FLOOD WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 10 AM EDT THURSDAY

entry.title: Coastal Flood Warning issued April 3 at 3:27PM EDT until April 4 at 12:00PM EDT by NWS Upton NY
entry.summary:
* WHAT...2 to 3 ft of inundation above ground level expected in vulnerable areas near the waterfront and shoreline Wednesday afternoon and night, locally 3 1/2 ft possible.
* WHERE...Northeast Suffolk, Southwest Suffolk, Southeast Suffolk and Southern Nassau Counties.
* WHEN...From 2 PM Wednesday to noon EDT Thursday.
* COASTAL FLOOD IMPACTS...Widespread flooding of vulnerable areas near the waterfront and shoreline, including roads, parking lots, parks, lawns, and homes and businesses with basements near the waterfront. Numerous road closures are likely, and vehicles parked in vulnerable areas near the waterfront will likely become flooded. Flooding will also extend inland from the waterfront along tidal rivers and bays.
* SHORELINE IMPACTS...Breaking waves of 6 to 10 ft this afternoon into Thursday morning, along with elevated water levels, will result in widespread beach flooding and erosion. Scattered areas of dune erosion with localized overwashes are likely during the times of high tide this afternoon thru Thursday morning. Along the twin forks, breaking waves of 4 to 8 ft this evening and Thursday morning, along with elevated water levels, will result in beach erosion with damage to shoreline structures possible. Wave splashover over bulkheads and seawalls will likely exacerbate flooding of shoreline roadways and properties.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...The combination of heavy rain and elevated water levels on this afternoon into evening may cause localized flash flooding along some shoreline roads and properties. The potential for locally major coastal flooding (around 3 ft of inundation above ground) late tonight into early Thu morning will be dependent on track of low pressure, and timing of windshift from easterly gales to northwest gales. To account for this forecast uncertainty, a slight upward safety margin has been applied to the forecast water levels.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Northeast Suffolk; Southwest Suffolk; Southeast Suffolk; Southern Nassau

entry.title: Avalanche Watch issued April 2 at 1:37PM EDT by NWS Gray ME
entry.summary:
AVAGYX
The following message is transmitted at the request of the Forest Service Mount Washington Avalanche Center, Gorham NH.
The US Forest Service Mount Washington Avalanche Center has issued a backcountry avalanche watch. This avalanche watch does not apply to operating ski areas.
* WHAT...A significant winter storm, bringing the possibility of 30+ inches of snow and strong wind to the higher summits in the Presidential Range, will create dangerous avalanche conditions.
* WHERE...The Presidential Range avalanche forecast area, including but not limited to Tuckerman Ravine, Huntington Ravine, Gulf of Slides, Great Gulf, King Ravine, Burt Ravine, Ammonoosuc Ravine, Oakes Gulf and steep, open terrain in the mountains that are bounded by US Rt 2, US Rt 302, and NH Rt 16. This includes hiking trails that traverse across steep terrain like Summer Lion Head trail. Similar avalanche danger may exist at locations outside of the coverage area where steep, open terrain exists that has collected drifted snow.
* WHEN...In effect from Tue 16:00 EDT to Fri 16:00 EDT.
* IMPACTS... Large, destructive avalanches are likely to occur naturally and spontaneously and will exist throughout steep terrain including hiking trails. These avalanches may be large enough to bury multiple people, do significant damage to trees or buildings, and will likely run far down in paths or areas that are normally safe zones. Precipitation rates are forecast to be heavy, with 1-2 inches of snow falling per hour at times and visibility limited.
